trans-unit.source: How to use Queue storage from PHP | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Queue storage from PHP | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure Queue storage service to create and delete queues, and insert, get, and delete messages.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure Queue storage service to create and delete queues, and insert, get, and delete messages.

trans-unit.source: Samples are written in PHP.
trans-unit.target: Samples are written in PHP.

trans-unit.source: How to use Queue storage from PHP
trans-unit.target: How to use Queue storage from PHP

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios by using the Azure Queue storage service.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show you how to perform common scenarios by using the Azure Queue storage service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written via classes from the Windows SDK for PHP.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written via classes from the Windows SDK for PHP.

trans-unit.source: The covered scenarios include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.
trans-unit.target: The covered scenarios include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.

trans-unit.source: Create a PHP application
trans-unit.target: Create a PHP application

trans-unit.source: The only requirement for creating a PHP application that accesses Azure Queue storage is the referencing of classes from the Azure SDK for PHP from within your code.
trans-unit.target: The only requirement for creating a PHP application that accesses Azure Queue storage is the referencing of classes from the Azure SDK for PHP from within your code.

trans-unit.source: You can use any development tools to create your application, including Notepad.
trans-unit.target: You can use any development tools to create your application, including Notepad.

trans-unit.source: In this guide, you will use Queue storage features that can be called within a PHP application locally, or in code running within an Azure web role, worker role, or website.
trans-unit.target: In this guide, you will use Queue storage features that can be called within a PHP application locally, or in code running within an Azure web role, worker role, or website.

trans-unit.source: Get the Azure Client Libraries
trans-unit.target: Get the Azure Client Libraries

trans-unit.source: Configure your application to access Queue storage
trans-unit.target: Configure your application to access Queue storage

trans-unit.source: To use the APIs for Azure Queue storage, you need to:
trans-unit.target: To use the APIs for Azure Queue storage, you need to:

trans-unit.source: Reference the autoloader file by using the [require_once][require_once] statement.
trans-unit.target: Reference the autoloader file by using the [require_once][require_once] statement.

trans-unit.source: Reference any classes that you might use.
trans-unit.target: Reference any classes that you might use.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to include the autoloader file and reference the **ServicesBuilder** class.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to include the autoloader file and reference the **ServicesBuilder** class.

trans-unit.source: This example (and other examples in this article) assumes that you have installed the PHP Client Libraries for Azure via Composer.
trans-unit.target: This example (and other examples in this article) assumes that you have installed the PHP Client Libraries for Azure via Composer.

trans-unit.source: If you installed the libraries manually or as a PEAR package, you will need to reference the `WindowsAzure.php` autoloader file.
trans-unit.target: If you installed the libraries manually or as a PEAR package, you will need to reference the `WindowsAzure.php` autoloader file.

trans-unit.source: In the examples below, the `require_once` statement will be shown always, but only the classes that are necessary for the example to execute will be referenced.
trans-unit.target: In the examples below, the `require_once` statement will be shown always, but only the classes that are necessary for the example to execute will be referenced.

trans-unit.source: Set up an Azure storage connection
trans-unit.target: Set up an Azure storage connection

trans-unit.source: To instantiate an Azure Queue storage client, you must first have a valid connection string.
trans-unit.target: To instantiate an Azure Queue storage client, you must first have a valid connection string.

trans-unit.source: The format for the queue service connection string is as follows.
trans-unit.target: The format for the queue service connection string is as follows.

trans-unit.source: For accessing a live service:
trans-unit.target: For accessing a live service:

trans-unit.source: For accessing the emulator storage:
trans-unit.target: For accessing the emulator storage:

trans-unit.source: To create any Azure service client, you need to use the **ServicesBuilder** class.
trans-unit.target: To create any Azure service client, you need to use the **ServicesBuilder** class.

trans-unit.source: You can use either of the following techniques:
trans-unit.target: You can use either of the following techniques:

trans-unit.source: Pass the connection string directly to it.
trans-unit.target: Pass the connection string directly to it.

trans-unit.source: Use **CloudConfigurationManager (CCM)** to check multiple external sources for the connection string:
trans-unit.target: Use **CloudConfigurationManager (CCM)** to check multiple external sources for the connection string:

trans-unit.source: By default, it comes with support for one external source—environmental variables.
trans-unit.target: By default, it comes with support for one external source—environmental variables.

trans-unit.source: You can add new sources by extending the **ConnectionStringSource** class.
trans-unit.target: You can add new sources by extending the **ConnectionStringSource** class.

trans-unit.source: For the examples outlined here, the connection string will be passed directly.
trans-unit.target: For the examples outlined here, the connection string will be passed directly.

trans-unit.source: Create a queue
trans-unit.target: Create a queue

trans-unit.source: A **QueueRestProxy** object lets you create a queue by using the **createQueue** method.
trans-unit.target: A **QueueRestProxy** object lets you create a queue by using the **createQueue** method.

trans-unit.source: When creating a queue, you can set options on the queue, but doing so is not required.
trans-unit.target: When creating a queue, you can set options on the queue, but doing so is not required.

trans-unit.source: (The example below shows how to set metadata on a queue.)
trans-unit.target: (The example below shows how to set metadata on a queue.)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You should not rely on case sensitivity for metadata keys.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You should not rely on case sensitivity for metadata keys.

trans-unit.source: All keys are read from the service in lowercase.
trans-unit.target: All keys are read from the service in lowercase.

trans-unit.source: Add a message to a queue
trans-unit.target: Add a message to a queue

trans-unit.source: To add a message to a queue, use **QueueRestProxy->createMessage**.
trans-unit.target: To add a message to a queue, use **QueueRestProxy->createMessage**.

trans-unit.source: The method takes the queue name, the message text, and message options (which are optional).
trans-unit.target: The method takes the queue name, the message text, and message options (which are optional).

trans-unit.source: Peek at the next message
trans-unit.target: Peek at the next message

trans-unit.source: You can peek at a message (or messages) at the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling **QueueRestProxy->peekMessages**.
trans-unit.target: You can peek at a message (or messages) at the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling **QueueRestProxy->peekMessages**.

trans-unit.source: By default, the **peekMessage** method returns a single message, but you can change that value by using the **PeekMessagesOptions->setNumberOfMessages** method.
trans-unit.target: By default, the **peekMessage** method returns a single message, but you can change that value by using the **PeekMessagesOptions->setNumberOfMessages** method.

trans-unit.source: De-queue the next message
trans-unit.target: De-queue the next message

trans-unit.source: Your code removes a message from a queue in two steps.
trans-unit.target: Your code removes a message from a queue in two steps.

trans-unit.source: First, you call **QueueRestProxy->listMessages**, which makes the message invisible to any other code that's reading from the queue.
trans-unit.target: First, you call **QueueRestProxy->listMessages**, which makes the message invisible to any other code that's reading from the queue.

trans-unit.source: By default, this message will stay invisible for 30 seconds.
trans-unit.target: By default, this message will stay invisible for 30 seconds.

trans-unit.source: (If the message is not deleted in this time period, it will become visible on the queue again.) To finish removing the message from the queue, you must call **QueueRestProxy->deleteMessage**.
trans-unit.target: (If the message is not deleted in this time period, it will become visible on the queue again.) To finish removing the message from the queue, you must call **QueueRestProxy->deleteMessage**.

trans-unit.source: This two-step process of removing a message assures that when your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.
trans-unit.target: This two-step process of removing a message assures that when your code fails to process a message due to hardware or software failure, another instance of your code can get the same message and try again.

trans-unit.source: Your code calls **deleteMessage** right after the message has been processed.
trans-unit.target: Your code calls **deleteMessage** right after the message has been processed.

trans-unit.source: Change the contents of a queued message
trans-unit.target: Change the contents of a queued message

trans-unit.source: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue by calling **QueueRestProxy->updateMessage**.
trans-unit.target: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue by calling **QueueRestProxy->updateMessage**.

trans-unit.source: If the message represents a work task, you could use this feature to update the status of the work task.
trans-unit.target: If the message represents a work task, you could use this feature to update the status of the work task.

trans-unit.source: The following code updates the queue message with new contents, and it sets the visibility timeout to extend another 60 seconds.
trans-unit.target: The following code updates the queue message with new contents, and it sets the visibility timeout to extend another 60 seconds.

trans-unit.source: This saves the state of work that's associated with the message, and it gives the client another minute to continue working on the message.
trans-unit.target: This saves the state of work that's associated with the message, and it gives the client another minute to continue working on the message.

trans-unit.source: You could use this technique to track multi-step workflows on queue messages, without having to start over from the beginning if a processing step fails due to hardware or software failure.
trans-unit.target: You could use this technique to track multi-step workflows on queue messages, without having to start over from the beginning if a processing step fails due to hardware or software failure.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you would keep a retry count as well, and if the message is retried more than *n* times, you would delete it.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you would keep a retry count as well, and if the message is retried more than *n* times, you would delete it.

trans-unit.source: This protects against a message that triggers an application error each time it is processed.
trans-unit.target: This protects against a message that triggers an application error each time it is processed.

trans-unit.source: Additional options for de-queuing messages
trans-unit.target: Additional options for de-queuing messages

trans-unit.source: There are two ways that you can customize message retrieval from a queue.
trans-unit.target: There are two ways that you can customize message retrieval from a queue.

trans-unit.source: First, you can get a batch of messages (up to 32).
trans-unit.target: First, you can get a batch of messages (up to 32).

trans-unit.source: Second, you can set a longer or shorter visibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.
trans-unit.target: Second, you can set a longer or shorter visibility timeout, allowing your code more or less time to fully process each message.

trans-unit.source: The following code example uses the **getMessages** method to get 16 messages in one call.
trans-unit.target: The following code example uses the **getMessages** method to get 16 messages in one call.

trans-unit.source: Then it processes each message by using a **for** loop.
trans-unit.target: Then it processes each message by using a **for** loop.

trans-unit.source: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for each message.
trans-unit.target: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for each message.

trans-unit.source: Get queue length
trans-unit.target: Get queue length

trans-unit.source: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.
trans-unit.target: You can get an estimate of the number of messages in a queue.

trans-unit.source: The **QueueRestProxy->getQueueMetadata** method asks the queue service to return metadata about the queue.
trans-unit.target: The **QueueRestProxy->getQueueMetadata** method asks the queue service to return metadata about the queue.

trans-unit.source: Calling the **getApproximateMessageCount** method on the returned object provides a count of how many messages are in a queue.
trans-unit.target: Calling the **getApproximateMessageCount** method on the returned object provides a count of how many messages are in a queue.

trans-unit.source: The count is only approximate because messages can be added or removed after the queue service responds to your request.
trans-unit.target: The count is only approximate because messages can be added or removed after the queue service responds to your request.

trans-unit.source: Delete a queue
trans-unit.target: Delete a queue

trans-unit.source: To delete a queue and all the messages in it, call the **QueueRestProxy->deleteQueue** method.
trans-unit.target: To delete a queue and all the messages in it, call the **QueueRestProxy->deleteQueue** method.
